Liz Lemon.Action: Says 'Excuse me' multiple times trying to get past the moms blocking the entrance.
Backs up and runs over children to enter the bagel place when blocked.
Politely challenges a man cutting in line by saying 'Whoa, whoa, Excuse me. There's a line, buddy.'
Hands out bagels to everyone to make up for the cell phone guy's selfishness despite most throwing them away
Smiles embarrassedly and waves when introduced awkwardly by Kenneth in front of a tour group.
Complains about Kenneth embarrassing her in front of a tour group to Pete.
Appears embarrassed and passive when Kenneth embarrasses her in front of a tour group, does not assertively correct the situation herself.
Informs Pete about the inappropriate behavior of Kenneth so that he can handle it, showing delegation but not direct confrontation.
Manages a complex show as head writer (alluded to as 'front line' managing of sketches and content).
Interrupts writers' room discussion with an off-topic personal story (bagel story), losing the group's focus.
Offers to get the coffee maker and other items enthusiastically for the team after the bagel incident.
Encourages Josh with a supportive phrase: 'bend it, don’t break it.'
Enthusiastically volunteers to get what they want from Gary, showing initiative and confidence.
Displays quick wit in the interaction about fake cereal names, indicating intelligence and social skill.
Seems dependent on Gary to provide wants, showing some reliance on others rather than direct action.
Mentions trying a new restaurant and handling social attention from a waiter with humor and self-awareness about her limits with alcohol.
Accepts a cappuccino and is modestly acknowledged by colleagues for her effort.
Engages in conversation about a colleague's unfortunate death, showing curiosity and concern.
Questions quitting in the face of adversity, showing resilience.
Clarifies to Josh firmly that Lawrence Jordan will not be joining the cast or taking over for Jenna, maintaining control over the show's direction.
Does not intervene further after Josh seems uninformed about cast changes, simply says 'Nothing.'
Does not appear or act in the excerpt; no demonstration of skill or confidence.
Stops to help Jenna who is drunk and in a baby outfit, and pushes her down the street in a stroller despite the odd situation.
Jokes about killing someone after discussing making music more palatable for a mainstream audience, showing a sarcastic humor but no real malice.
Rejects Jenna’s party behavior with gentle insistence ('No, no. Come on, friend.'), indicating concern and care.
